news_summary: Today’s space news highlights international collaboration and innovation, with Spain investing to host a major telescope, Senegal joining the Artemis Accords, the successful rocket launch from Cape Canaveral, and NASA advancing AI technology to enhance Earth-observing satellites.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière la collaboration et l'innovation internationales : l'Espagne investit pour accueillir un grand télescope, le Sénégal adhère aux accords Artemis, le lancement réussi d'une fusée depuis Cap Canaveral et la NASA fait progresser la technologie de l'intelligence artificielle pour améliorer les satellites d'observation de la Terre.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan la colaboración y la innovación internacionales, con España invirtiendo para albergar un gran telescopio, Senegal uniéndose a los Acuerdos Artemis, el exitoso lanzamiento de un cohete desde Cabo Cañaveral y la NASA avanzando en la tecnología de IA para mejorar los satélites de observación de la Tierra.

articles.title: Spain bids €400 million to host mega telescope at risk in US budget cuts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01230-9New Canary Islands home could save controversial Thirty Meter Telescope first proposed for Hawaii.
articles.content:
The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT), a major international project long slated for construction in Hawaii, might be getting a new home.

Last month, the administration of US president Donald Trump announced plans to abandon further support for the telescope, as part of its proposals to slash by half funding for the US National Science Foundation (NSF), which has until now supported the telescope’s design.

Now the Spanish government has pitched to bring the giant facility to La Palma, in Spain’s Canary Islands — and backed up the effort with a pledge to contribute €400 million (US$470 million).

“Spain reinforces its commitment as a refuge for science, betting on excellent research and technological innovation,” wrote the Spanish minister for science and innovation, Diana Morant, on X, as she announced the funding on 23 July.

According to a statement from her ministry, Morant has already submitted a formal proposal to host the telescope to the TMT board, which would have to back such a move for it to go ahead. The TMT was “at risk of paralysis”, added the minister.

A new Generation

The telescope’s 30-metre light-collecting mirror would dwarf those of today’s best optical telescopes. It is one of three telescopes of this scale now under development, and which will allow astronomers to study the cosmos with unprecedented resolution. La Palma has long been mentioned as a back-up location for the telescope, should its development stall on Hawaii’s Mauna Kea mountain, where activists had opposed its construction. A disadvantage of the Spanish site is that, at 2,250 metres high, La Palma is lower than Mauna Kea‘s 4,050 metres. This means the telescope would have more atmosphere to see through, affecting the quality of the observations.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Spain's significant investment to host the Thirty Meter Telescope, which is at risk due to US budget cuts. This move represents international cooperation in advancing scientific research and preserving a major astronomical project, which is inspiring and hopeful for the scientific community and space exploration enthusiasts.
articles.personality_title: Spain steps up to save giant telescope with €400 million offer
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) is a huge and powerful telescope project initially planned to be built in Hawaii. It’s designed to help scientists explore space in more detail than ever before. However, recent budget cuts in the US threatened the project’s future, putting years of work and international collaboration at risk.

**What happened**
After the US announced it would stop funding the telescope due to budget cuts in the National Science Foundation, Spain offered a generous €400 million to host the TMT on the island of La Palma. This new location in the Canary Islands has clear skies and good conditions for astronomy, making it a great alternative to Hawaii.

**Impact**
Spain’s offer could save the TMT project from being canceled, keeping alive hopes for amazing new discoveries in space. It also shows how countries can work together to support important scientific efforts, even when challenges arise in one place.

**What’s next step**
The telescope’s international partners will now consider Spain’s proposal and decide if La Palma will become the new home for the TMT. This means planning the move, adjusting construction plans, and continuing the work to bring this incredible tool to life.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Spain’s bold investment keeps the dream of building a world-class telescope alive, showing how global teamwork can overcome obstacles in science.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'Espagne propose 400 millions d'euros pour sauver un télescope géant
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le Télescope de trente mètres (TMT) est un projet de télescope puissant initialement prévu à Hawaï. Il est conçu pour aider les scientifiques à explorer l’espace avec plus de précision que jamais. Pourtant, des coupes budgétaires récentes aux États-Unis ont menacé l’avenir du projet, mettant en danger des années de travail et de collaboration internationale.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Après l’annonce américaine de l’arrêt du financement du télescope à cause des coupes dans la National Science Foundation, l’Espagne a proposé une contribution généreuse de 400 millions d’euros pour accueillir le TMT sur l’île de La Palma. Ce nouvel emplacement dans les îles Canaries offre un ciel clair et des conditions idéales pour l’astronomie, une excellente alternative à Hawaï.

**Impact**
La proposition de l’Espagne pourrait sauver le projet TMT de l’annulation, maintenant ainsi l’espoir de découvertes spatiales incroyables. Cela montre aussi comment les pays peuvent collaborer pour soutenir des efforts scientifiques importants, même quand il y a des difficultés ailleurs.

**Prochaine étape**
Les partenaires internationaux du télescope vont maintenant étudier la proposition de l’Espagne pour décider si La Palma deviendra la nouvelle maison du TMT. Cela implique de planifier le transfert, d’adapter les plans de construction et de poursuivre les travaux pour concrétiser cet outil incroyable.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
L’investissement audacieux de l’Espagne maintient en vie le rêve de construire un télescope de classe mondiale, prouvant que la coopération mondiale peut surmonter les obstacles en science.
articles.personality_title_es: España ofrece 400 millones de euros para salvar un telescopio gigante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El Telescopio de treinta metros (TMT) es un proyecto de telescopio grande y poderoso originalmente planeado para construirse en Hawái. Está diseñado para ayudar a los científicos a explorar el espacio con más detalle que nunca. Sin embargo, recortes presupuestarios recientes en EE. UU. pusieron en riesgo el futuro del proyecto, amenazando años de trabajo y colaboración internacional.

**Qué pasó**
Después de que EE. UU. anunciara que dejaría de financiar el telescopio debido a recortes en la Fundación Nacional de Ciencias, España ofreció generosamente 400 millones de euros para alojar el TMT en la isla de La Palma. Esta nueva ubicación en las Islas Canarias tiene cielos claros y buenas condiciones para la astronomía, siendo una excelente alternativa a Hawái.

**Impacto**
La oferta de España podría salvar al proyecto TMT de ser cancelado, manteniendo viva la esperanza de increíbles descubrimientos espaciales. También muestra cómo los países pueden trabajar juntos para apoyar esfuerzos científicos importantes, incluso cuando surgen desafíos en otro lugar.

**Próximo paso**
Los socios internacionales del telescopio ahora considerarán la propuesta de España y decidirán si La Palma será el nuevo hogar del TMT. Esto implica planificar el traslado, ajustar los planes de construcción y continuar el trabajo para hacer realidad esta increíble herramienta.

**Frase clave**
La valiente inversión de España mantiene vivo el sueño de construir un telescopio de clase mundial, demostrando que el trabajo en equipo global puede superar obstáculos en la ciencia.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a majestic, large astronomical telescope with a shining 30-meter segmented mirror perched atop the volcanic peak of La Palma under a clear starry sky, with gentle outlines of the Canary Islands visible below and soft glowing light symbolizing international scientific collaboration and hope for new cosmic discoveries.

articles.title: NASA Welcomes Senegal as Newest Artemis Accords Signatory
articles.summary: Senegal signed the Artemis Accords Thursday during a ceremony hosted by NASA at the agency’s headquarters in Washington, becoming the latest nation to commit to the responsible exploration of space for all humanity. “Following a meeting between Senegal President Faye and President Trump, today, NASA built upon the strong relations between our two nations as […]
articles.content:
From left to right, Ambassador of Senegal to the United States Abdoul Wahab Haidara, Director General of the Senegalese space agency (ASES) Maram Kairé, NASA Chief of Staff Brian Hughes, and Department of State Bureau of African Affairs Senior Bureau Official Jonathan Pratt pose for a photo during an Artemis Accords signing ceremony Thursday, July 24, 2025, at the Mary W. Jackson NASA Headquarters building in Washington. Senegal is the 56th country to sign the Artemis Accords, which establish a practical set of principles to guide space exploration cooperation among nations participating in NASA’s Artemis program. Credit: NASA/Keegan Barber

Senegal signed the Artemis Accords Thursday during a ceremony hosted by NASA at the agency’s headquarters in Washington, becoming the latest nation to commit to the responsible exploration of space for all humanity.

“Following a meeting between Senegal President Faye and President Trump, today, NASA built upon the strong relations between our two nations as the Senegalese Agency for Space Studies signed the Artemis Accords,” said acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy. “With Senegal as the 56th signatory, I am proud to further President Trump’s strong legacy of global cooperation in space.”

Director General of the Senegalese space agency (ASES) Maram Kairé signed the Artemis Accords on behalf of Senegal. Jonathan Pratt, senior bureau official for African Affairs at the U.S. Department of State, and Abdoul Wahab Haidara, ambassador of Senegal to the United States, also participated in the event.

“Senegal’s adherence to the Artemis Accords reflects our commitment to a multilateral, responsible, and transparent approach to space,” said Kairé. “This signature marks a meaningful step in our space diplomacy and in our ambition to contribute to the peaceful exploration of outer space.”

The Artemis Accords signing ceremony took place two weeks after President Trump’s meeting in Washington with Senegal’s President Bassirou Diomaye Faye and other countries of Africa focused on U.S.-Africa engagement.

Astronomers from Senegal have supported NASA missions by participating in multiple observations when asteroids or planets pass in front of stars, casting shadows on Earth. In 2021, NASA also collaborated with Kairé and a group of astronomers for a ground observation campaign in Senegal. As the asteroid Orus passed in front of a star, they positioned telescopes along the path of the asteroid’s shadow to estimate its shape and size. NASA’s Lucy spacecraft will approach Orus in 2028, as part of its mission to explore Jupiter’s Trojan asteroids.

In 2020, during the first Trump Administration, the United States, led by NASA and the U.S. Department of State, joined with seven other founding nations to establish the Artemis Accords, responding to the growing interest in lunar activities by both governments and private companies.

The accords introduced the first set of practical principles aimed at enhancing the safety, transparency, and coordination of civil space exploration on the Moon, Mars, and beyond.

Signing the Artemis Accords means to explore peaceably and transparently, to render aid to those in need, to ensure unrestricted access to scientific data that all of humanity can learn from, to ensure activities do not interfere with those of others, to preserve historically significant sites and artifacts, and to develop best practices for how to conduct space exploration activities for the benefit of all.

More countries are expected to sign the Artemis Accords in the months and years ahead, as NASA continues its work to establish a safe, peaceful, and prosperous future in space.

Learn more about the Artemis Accords at:

https://www.nasa.gov/artemis-accords

-end-

Bethany Stevens / Elizabeth Shaw

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1600

bethany.c.stevens@nasa.gov / elizabeth.a.shaw@nasa.gov
articles.reasoning: Senegal joining the Artemis Accords represents international cooperation and commitment to responsible space exploration, which is a positive step for humanity's future in space and scientific advancement.
articles.personality_title: Senegal joins NASA’s Artemis Accords for responsible space exploration
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
NASA has created the Artemis Accords, a set of agreements encouraging countries to work together and explore space responsibly and peacefully. These accords promote safety, transparency, and fairness in space activities for the benefit of all humanity.

**What happened**
Senegal officially signed the Artemis Accords during a special ceremony at NASA’s headquarters in Washington. This made Senegal the 56th country to commit to these space exploration principles. Senegal’s participation follows positive discussions between its president and U.S. leaders, strengthening ties between the two nations.

**Impact**
By joining the Artemis Accords, Senegal is helping build a global community dedicated to peaceful and responsible space exploration. This cooperation supports scientific progress and ensures space remains a place where countries work together rather than compete.

**What's next step**
Senegal will collaborate with NASA and other signatory countries on future space missions and share knowledge through the Artemis program. This partnership opens new opportunities for Senegalese scientists and engineers to contribute to humanity’s journey to the Moon and beyond.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Senegal’s commitment to the Artemis Accords marks an inspiring moment of international teamwork for the peaceful future of space exploration.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Sénégal rejoint les accords Artemis de la NASA pour une exploration spatiale responsable
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La NASA a créé les accords Artemis, un ensemble d’accords encourageant les pays à collaborer pour explorer l’espace de manière responsable et pacifique. Ces accords favorisent la sécurité, la transparence et l’équité dans les activités spatiales au bénéfice de toute l’humanité.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Le Sénégal a officiellement signé les accords Artemis lors d’une cérémonie spéciale au siège de la NASA à Washington. Cela fait du Sénégal le 56e pays à s’engager dans ces principes d’exploration spatiale. La participation du Sénégal suit des discussions positives entre son président et les dirigeants américains, renforçant les liens entre les deux nations.

**Impact**
En rejoignant les accords Artemis, le Sénégal contribue à bâtir une communauté mondiale dédiée à une exploration spatiale pacifique et responsable. Cette coopération soutient le progrès scientifique et garantit que l’espace reste un lieu de collaboration plutôt que de compétition.

**La prochaine étape**
Le Sénégal collaborera avec la NASA et les autres pays signataires sur de futures missions spatiales et partagera ses connaissances dans le cadre du programme Artemis. Ce partenariat ouvre de nouvelles opportunités pour les scientifiques et ingénieurs sénégalais dans le voyage de l’humanité vers la Lune et au-delà.

**En une phrase**
L’engagement du Sénégal envers les accords Artemis représente un moment inspirant de coopération internationale pour un avenir pacifique de l’exploration spatiale.
articles.personality_title_es: Senegal se une a los Acuerdos Artemis de la NASA para una exploración espacial responsable
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La NASA creó los Acuerdos Artemis, un conjunto de compromisos que fomentan la colaboración entre países para explorar el espacio de manera responsable y pacífica. Estos acuerdos promueven la seguridad, transparencia y equidad en las actividades espaciales para beneficio de toda la humanidad.

**Qué pasó**
Senegal firmó oficialmente los Acuerdos Artemis en una ceremonia especial en la sede de la NASA en Washington. Esto convierte a Senegal en el país número 56 en comprometerse con estos principios de exploración espacial. La participación de Senegal siguió a conversaciones positivas entre su presidente y líderes estadounidenses, fortaleciendo los lazos entre ambas naciones.

**Impacto**
Al unirse a los Acuerdos Artemis, Senegal contribuye a construir una comunidad global dedicada a la exploración espacial pacífica y responsable. Esta colaboración apoya el avance científico y asegura que el espacio siga siendo un lugar de trabajo conjunto en lugar de competencia.

**Próximo paso**
Senegal colaborará con la NASA y otros países firmantes en futuras misiones espaciales y compartirá conocimientos a través del programa Artemis. Esta asociación abre nuevas oportunidades para que científicos e ingenieros senegaleses contribuyan al viaje de la humanidad hacia la Luna y más allá.

**En una frase**
El compromiso de Senegal con los Acuerdos Artemis marca un momento inspirador de trabajo en equipo internacional para el futuro pacífico de la exploración espacial.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of four glowing, intertwined stars above a stylized lunar surface, each star gently connected by shimmering cosmic threads symbolizing international cooperation; beneath, a smooth crescent moon cradles a small, vibrant baobab tree representing Senegal’s growing role in peaceful space exploration, all rendered in soft, natural hues of deep blue, silver, and earthy greens on a calm night sky background.

articles.title: First Rocket Launch from Cape Canaveral
articles.summary: The Bumper V-2 launches from Cape Canaveral in this July 24, 1950, photo. In the 75 years since this milestone, this facility has seen thousands of rockets take to the skies, destined for Earth orbit, the Moon, planets, and even beyond. From Cape Canaveral and from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida nearby, astronauts launched […]
articles.content:
NASA

The Bumper V-2 launches from Cape Canaveral in this July 24, 1950, photo. In the 75 years since this milestone, this facility has seen thousands of rockets take to the skies, destined for Earth orbit, the Moon, planets, and even beyond. From Cape Canaveral and from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida nearby, astronauts launched on the first pioneering crewed missions, headed for Moon landings, and helped to build the International Space Station.

NASA Kennedy, a premier multi-user spaceport with about 100 private-sector partners and nearly 250 partnership agreements, is still the agency’s main launch site. NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission, part of the agency’s Commercial Crew Program, will launch from NASA Kennedy no earlier than 12:09 p.m. EDT, Thursday, July 31. The Crew-11 mission members – NASA astronauts Zena Cardman and Mike Fincke, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Kimiya Yui, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov – are in crew quarantine before their voyage to the orbital laboratory.

Image credit: NASA
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a historic milestone in space exploration, celebrating the first rocket launch from Cape Canaveral and the subsequent achievements in space travel. This represents scientific progress and human achievement, which are generally uplifting and inspiring to a wide audience.
articles.personality_title: Celebrating 75 years since Cape Canaveral’s first rocket launch
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
On July 24, 1950, the Bumper V-2 rocket was launched from Cape Canaveral, marking the beginning of a remarkable journey for this launch site. Over the last 75 years, it has become a key gateway for space exploration.

**What happened**
That first launch was the start of thousands of rockets taking off from Cape Canaveral and the nearby Kennedy Space Center in Florida. These launches have sent satellites into Earth’s orbit, astronauts to the Moon, and spacecraft to other planets and beyond.

**Impact**
This site has played a crucial role in human spaceflight, including pioneering crewed missions and the construction of the International Space Station. It symbolizes human curiosity, scientific progress, and the spirit of exploration.

**What's next step**
Cape Canaveral and Kennedy Space Center will continue to support new missions, including future Moon landings and exploration of Mars, keeping humanity’s journey into space alive and growing.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Cape Canaveral’s first rocket launch 75 years ago opened the door to decades of incredible achievements that continue to inspire and push humanity forward into space.
articles.personality_title_fr: Célébration des 75 ans du premier lancement de fusée à Cap Canaveral
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le 24 juillet 1950, la fusée Bumper V-2 a été lancée depuis Cap Canaveral, marquant le début d’une aventure remarquable pour ce site de lancement. Depuis 75 ans, il est devenu une porte d’entrée essentielle pour l’exploration spatiale.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Ce premier lancement a été le départ de milliers de fusées décollant de Cap Canaveral et du centre spatial Kennedy voisin en Floride. Ces lancements ont envoyé des satellites en orbite terrestre, des astronautes sur la Lune, et des engins spatiaux vers d’autres planètes et au-delà.

**Impact**
Ce site a joué un rôle crucial dans le vol spatial habité, y compris les missions pionnières et la construction de la Station spatiale internationale. Il symbolise la curiosité humaine, le progrès scientifique et l’esprit d’exploration.

**Prochaine étape**
Cap Canaveral et le centre Kennedy continueront de soutenir de nouvelles missions, notamment les futurs atterrissages lunaires et l’exploration de Mars, poursuivant ainsi le voyage de l’humanité dans l’espace.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Le premier lancement de fusée à Cap Canaveral il y a 75 ans a ouvert la voie à des décennies de réalisations incroyables qui continuent d’inspirer et de faire avancer l’humanité dans l’espace.
articles.personality_title_es: Celebrando 75 años desde el primer lanzamiento de cohete en Cabo Cañaveral
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El 24 de julio de 1950, el cohete Bumper V-2 fue lanzado desde Cabo Cañaveral, marcando el inicio de un viaje extraordinario para este sitio de lanzamiento. En los últimos 75 años, se ha convertido en una puerta clave para la exploración espacial.

**Qué pasó**
Ese primer lanzamiento fue el inicio de miles de cohetes despegando desde Cabo Cañaveral y el cercano Centro Espacial Kennedy en Florida. Estos lanzamientos han enviado satélites a la órbita terrestre, astronautas a la Luna y naves a otros planetas y más allá.

**Impacto**
Este sitio ha jugado un papel crucial en el vuelo espacial tripulado, incluyendo misiones pioneras y la construcción de la Estación Espacial Internacional. Representa la curiosidad humana, el progreso científico y el espíritu de exploración.

**Próximo paso**
Cabo Cañaveral y el Centro Kennedy continuarán apoyando nuevas misiones, incluyendo futuros aterrizajes en la Luna y la exploración de Marte, manteniendo viva y creciendo la aventura humana en el espacio.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El primer lanzamiento de cohete en Cabo Cañaveral hace 75 años abrió la puerta a décadas de increíbles logros que continúan inspirando y llevando a la humanidad hacia el espacio.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vintage rocket launching from a sandy Florida coastline at dawn, with soft natural hues of blue sky, gentle orange sunrise, and the tall slender rocket silhouette rising boldly into the sky, symbolizing the dawn of space exploration and the enduring legacy of Cape Canaveral’s historic launches.

articles.title: How NASA Is Testing AI to Make Earth-Observing Satellites Smarter
articles.summary: A technology called Dynamic Targeting could enable spacecraft to decide, autonomously and within seconds, where to best make science observations from orbit. In a recent test, NASA showed how artificial intelligence-based technology could help orbiting spacecraft provide more targeted and valuable science data. The technology enabled an Earth-observing satellite for the first time to look […]
articles.content:
Cloud cover can keep optical instruments on satellites from clearly capturing Earth’s surface. Still in testing, JPL’s Dynamic Targeting uses AI to avoid imaging clouds, yielding a higher proportion of usable data, and to focus on phenomena like this 2015 volcanic eruption in Indonesia Landsat 8 captured. NASA/USGS

A technology called Dynamic Targeting could enable spacecraft to decide, autonomously and within seconds, where to best make science observations from orbit.

In a recent test, NASA showed how artificial intelligence-based technology could help orbiting spacecraft provide more targeted and valuable science data. The technology enabled an Earth-observing satellite for the first time to look ahead along its orbital path, rapidly process and analyze imagery with onboard AI, and determine where to point an instrument. The whole process took less than 90 seconds, without any human involvement.

Called Dynamic Targeting, the concept has been in development for more than a decade at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California. The first of a series of flight tests occurred aboard a commercial satellite in mid-July. The goal: to show the potential of Dynamic Targeting to enable orbiters to improve ground imaging by avoiding clouds and also to autonomously hunt for specific, short-lived phenomena like wildfires, volcanic eruptions, and rare storms.

This graphic shows how JPL’s Dynamic Targeting uses a lookahead sensor to see what’s on a satellite’s upcoming path. Onboard algorithms process the sensor’s data, identifying clouds to avoid and targets of interest for closer observation as the satellite passes overhead. NASA/JPL-Caltech

“The idea is to make the spacecraft act more like a human: Instead of just seeing data, it’s thinking about what the data shows and how to respond,” says Steve Chien, a technical fellow in AI at JPL and principal investigator for the Dynamic Targeting project. “When a human sees a picture of trees burning, they understand it may indicate a forest fire, not just a collection of red and orange pixels. We’re trying to make the spacecraft have the ability to say, ‘That’s a fire,’ and then focus its sensors on the fire.”

Avoiding Clouds for Better Science

This first flight test for Dynamic Targeting wasn’t hunting specific phenomena like fires — that will come later. Instead, the point was avoiding an omnipresent phenomenon: clouds.

Most science instruments on orbiting spacecraft look down at whatever is beneath them. However, for Earth-observing satellites with optical sensors, clouds can get in the way as much as two-thirds of the time, blocking views of the surface. To overcome this, Dynamic Targeting looks 300 miles (500 kilometers) ahead and has the ability to distinguish between clouds and clear sky. If the scene is clear, the spacecraft images the surface when passing overhead. If it’s cloudy, the spacecraft cancels the imaging activity to save data storage for another target.

“If you can be smart about what you’re taking pictures of, then you only image the ground and skip the clouds. That way, you’re not storing, processing, and downloading all this imagery researchers really can’t use,” said Ben Smith of JPL, an associate with NASA’s Earth Science Technology Office, which funds the Dynamic Targeting work. “This technology will help scientists get a much higher proportion of usable data.”

How Dynamic Targeting Works

The testing is taking place on CogniSAT-6, a briefcase-size CubeSat that launched in March 2024. The satellite — designed, built, and operated by Open Cosmos — hosts a payload designed and developed by Ubotica featuring a commercially available AI processor. While working with Ubotica in 2022, Chien’s team conducted tests aboard the International Space Station running algorithms similar to those in Dynamic Targeting on the same type of processor. The results showed the combination could work for space-based remote sensing.

Since CogniSAT-6 lacks an imager dedicated to looking ahead, the spacecraft tilts forward 40 to 50 degrees to point its optical sensor, a camera that sees both visible and near-infrared light. Once look-ahead imagery has been acquired, Dynamic Targeting’s advanced algorithm, trained to identify clouds, analyzes it. Based on that analysis, the Dynamic Targeting planning software determines where to point the sensor for cloud-free views. Meanwhile, the satellite tilts back toward nadir (looking directly below the spacecraft) and snaps the planned imagery, capturing only the ground.

This all takes place in 60 to 90 seconds, depending on the original look-ahead angle, as the spacecraft speeds in low Earth orbit at nearly 17,000 mph (7.5 kilometers per second).

What’s Next

With the cloud-avoidance capability now proven, the next test will be hunting for storms and severe weather — essentially targeting clouds instead of avoiding them. Another test will be to search for thermal anomalies like wildfires and volcanic eruptions. The JPL team developed unique algorithms for each application.

“This initial deployment of Dynamic Targeting is a hugely important step,” Chien said. “The end goal is operational use on a science mission, making for a very agile instrument taking novel measurements.”

There are multiple visions for how that could happen — possibly even on spacecraft exploring the solar system. In fact, Chien and his JPL colleagues drew some inspiration for their Dynamic Targeting work from another project they had also worked on: using data from ESA’s (the European Space Agency’s) Rosetta orbiter to demonstrate the feasibility of autonomously detecting and imaging plumes emitted by comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

On Earth, adapting Dynamic Targeting for use with radar could allow scientists to study dangerous extreme winter weather events called deep convective ice storms, which are too rare and short-lived to closely observe with existing technologies. Specialized algorithms would identify these dense storm formations with a satellite’s look-ahead instrument. Then a powerful, focused radar would pivot to keep the ice clouds in view, “staring” at them as the spacecraft speeds by overhead and gathers a bounty of data over six to eight minutes.

Some ideas involve using Dynamic Targeting on multiple spacecraft: The results of onboard image analysis from a leading satellite could be rapidly communicated to a trailing satellite, which could be tasked with targeting specific phenomena. The data could even be fed to a constellation of dozens of orbiting spacecraft. Chien is leading a test of that concept, called Federated Autonomous MEasurement, beginning later this year.

News Media Contact

Melissa Pamer

Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif.

626-314-4928

melissa.pamer@jpl.nasa.gov

2025-094
articles.reasoning: The article describes NASA's successful testing of AI technology that enables satellites to autonomously make smarter decisions for Earth observation, which represents a significant technological advancement with potential benefits for science and environmental monitoring.
articles.personality_title: NASA tests smart AI to help satellites spot Earth’s secrets faster
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Watching Earth from space is tricky because clouds often block satellites’ view, making it hard to get clear pictures. NASA wants to improve how satellites gather information about our planet to better track important events like volcanic eruptions or natural disasters.

**What happened**
NASA tested a new AI technology called Dynamic Targeting that lets satellites decide on their own, within seconds, where to look for the most useful science data. This AI helps satellites avoid cloudy areas and focus on clear spots or interesting events, like a volcanic eruption in Indonesia captured earlier.

**Impact**
By using AI to quickly pick the best observation spots, satellites can provide more valuable and reliable information. This means scientists get better data to study Earth’s changes, monitor disasters, and protect the environment more effectively.

**What’s next step**
NASA will continue refining this AI technology to make it even smarter and more reliable. They plan to use it on future satellites, helping Earth observation missions become faster and more efficient.

**One-sentence takeaway**
NASA’s AI-powered Dynamic Targeting helps satellites see through clouds and focus on important Earth events, making space observations smarter and more useful.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA teste une IA intelligente pour aider les satellites à mieux observer la Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Observer la Terre depuis l'espace est difficile car les nuages bloquent souvent la vue des satellites, rendant les images floues. La NASA veut améliorer la collecte d’informations pour mieux suivre des événements importants comme les éruptions volcaniques ou les catastrophes naturelles.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
La NASA a testé une nouvelle technologie d’IA appelée Dynamic Targeting qui permet aux satellites de choisir eux-mêmes, en quelques secondes, où regarder pour obtenir les données scientifiques les plus utiles. Cette IA aide les satellites à éviter les zones nuageuses et à se concentrer sur des endroits clairs ou des événements intéressants, comme une éruption volcanique en Indonésie.

**Impact**
En utilisant l’IA pour choisir rapidement les meilleurs endroits d’observation, les satellites fournissent des informations plus précieuses et fiables. Cela permet aux scientifiques d’avoir de meilleures données pour étudier les changements terrestres, surveiller les catastrophes et protéger l’environnement.

**Prochaine étape**
La NASA va continuer à améliorer cette technologie d’IA pour la rendre encore plus intelligente et fiable. Elle prévoit de l’utiliser sur de futurs satellites pour rendre les missions d’observation de la Terre plus rapides et efficaces.

**À retenir en une phrase**
La technologie IA Dynamic Targeting de la NASA aide les satellites à voir à travers les nuages et à se concentrer sur les événements importants, rendant l’observation spatiale plus intelligente et utile.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA prueba IA inteligente para ayudar a los satélites a observar mejor la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Observar la Tierra desde el espacio es difícil porque las nubes a menudo bloquean la vista de los satélites, dificultando obtener imágenes claras. La NASA quiere mejorar cómo los satélites recopilan información para seguir mejor eventos importantes como erupciones volcánicas o desastres naturales.

**Qué pasó**
La NASA probó una nueva tecnología de IA llamada Dynamic Targeting que permite a los satélites decidir por sí solos, en segundos, dónde observar para obtener los datos científicos más útiles. Esta IA ayuda a los satélites a evitar áreas nubladas y enfocarse en zonas claras o eventos interesantes, como una erupción volcánica en Indonesia.

**Impacto**
Al usar IA para elegir rápidamente los mejores lugares de observación, los satélites pueden proporcionar información más valiosa y confiable. Esto permite a los científicos obtener mejores datos para estudiar los cambios en la Tierra, monitorear desastres y proteger el medio ambiente.

**Próximo paso**
La NASA seguirá mejorando esta tecnología de IA para hacerla más inteligente y confiable. Planea usarla en futuros satélites para que las misiones de observación terrestre sean más rápidas y eficientes.

**Resumen en una frase**
La tecnología IA Dynamic Targeting de la NASA ayuda a los satélites a ver a través de las nubes y concentrarse en eventos importantes, haciendo que la observación espacial sea más inteligente y útil.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a sleek satellite orbiting Earth with a glowing, stylized AI brain symbol integrated into its design, scanning a cloud-covered landscape below while a clear, cloud-free path ahead is illuminated, using soft blues, gentle grays, and warm earth tones to convey smart, autonomous observation and dynamic targeting in space.
